revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Nina Conti | birth_name = Nina Margarita Conti | image = Nina Conti and Monk 2010.jpg | caption = Conti performing with Monk at the [[Glastonbury Festival 2010]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|6|5|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Hampstead]], London, England | medium = Actress, [[ventriloquist]] | nationality = British | active = | genre = Ventriloquism, comedy | spouse = Andrew "Stan" Stanley | children = 2 | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = {{URL|www.ninaconti.net}} | footnotes = | parents = [[Tom Conti]]
[[Kara Wilson]] | module = {{Listen| embed=yes |filename = Nina Conti BBC Radio4 Woman's Hour 6 Jul 2012 b01jhjc9.flac |title = Conti's voice |type = speech |description = from the BBC programme [[Woman's Hour]], 6 July 2012{{Cite episode |title= Nina Conti |series= Woman's Hour |serieslink= Woman's Hour |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01jhjc9 |accessdate= 2014-01-18 |station= BBC Radio 4 |date= 6 July 2012 |season= |seriesno= |number= |transcript= |transcripturl= }} }} }} '''Nina Margarita Conti''' (born 5 June 1974) is an English actor, comedian, and [[ventriloquist]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/nina-conti/bio/552228 |title=Nina Conti Biography |publisher=TVGuide.com |accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=rmRYjZFaH5BBWUa2wtHurA&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=16 November 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}}{{cite news |last=Fulton |first=Rick |date=16 July 2012 |title=Tom Conti's daughter Nina proves she's no muppet for working with dummies ahead of Edinburgh Festival appearance |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/celebrity/tom-contis-daughter-nina-proves-1166927 |newspaper=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |access-date=16 November 2016}} Her primary on-stage puppets are a white-haired Scottish grandmother named Granny and a deadpan monkey named Monk. == Early life == Conti was born and raised in [[Hampstead]], [[London]], the daughter of actors [[Tom Conti]] and [[Kara Wilson]].{{cite news |last=MacInnes |first=Paul |date=11 August 2008 |title=Edinburgh festival rapid review: Nina Conti |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/aug/11/edinburgh.nina.conti |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=9 August 2009}} She was educated at [[King Alfred School, London]], and graduated with a first class honours degree in Philosophy from the [[University of East Anglia]] in 1995.{{cite news |last=Hattenstone |first=Simon |date=14 December 2013 |title=Comedians and their parents: Nina Conti and father Tom |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2013/dec/14/nina-conti-tom-conti-relationship |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=16 November 2016}} == Acting == Conti has worked as an actor since 1996. She appeared in several roles in Daisy and [[Ken Campbell]]'s 1999 and 2000 productions of ''The Warp'', [[Neil Oram]]'s 24-hour [[play cycle]], and was a member of the [[Royal Shakespeare Company|RSC]]'s 2000/2001 company in [[Stratford-upon-Avon|Stratford]] and London. Ken Campbell subsequently devised the ventriloquist play ''Let Me Out!!!'' for her, which she took to the [[2001 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]]. She appeared as half-Afghan camera operator Azadine in [[Henry Naylor]]'s play ''Finding Bin Laden'' at the [[2003 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]]. In 2005, Conti voiced Latrina in the animated comedy series ''[[Bromwell High]]''. Conti has appeared in several television shows, including ''[[Black Books]]'', ''[[Holby City]]'', ''Single'', and the Australian panel show ''[[Spicks and Specks (TV series)|Spicks and Specks]]''. Her radio performances include characters in Radio 4 comedy ''[[Clare in the Community#Radio series|Clare in the Community]]''. Conti and Monk portrayed a morning [[Weather forecasting|weather team]] on the fictional "Wake Up L.A." in [[Christopher Guest]]'s 2006 film, ''[[For Your Consideration (film)|For Your Consideration]]''.{{cite news|last=Humphreys |first=Jemma |date=2 May 2008 |title=Interview: Nina Conti |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/2257572.Interview__Nina_Conti/ |newspaper=[[Lancashire Telegraph]] |accessdate=8 June 2012}} Conti was awarded joint "Best Performance" in the Maverick Movie Awards for [[Her Master's Voice (2012 film)|''Her Master's Voice'']], a 2012 film.{{cite web|url=http://www.maverickmovieawards.com/features2012.html |title=2012 - Maverick Movie Awards! Where moviemakers honor moviemakers from all over the world! |publisher=Maverickmovieawards.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-18}} In 2013, she portrayed the part of Bea Chadwick in Christopher Guest's [[HBO]] [[mockumentary]] ''[[Family Tree (TV series)|Family Tree]]''. == Stand-up comedy == In 2002, Conti won the [[BBC New Comedy Awards]], came second in the [[Hackney Empire New Act of the Year]] and came third in "Laughing Horse New Act of the Year" competitions. Conti regularly headlines at London comedy venues and has appeared at [[The Comedy Store, London|The Comedy Store]]. She took her first solo full-length show, ''Complete and Utter Conti'', to the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in [[2007 Edinburgh Festival Fringe|2007]], where she introduced some new characters as well as performing familiar routines. In 2008 she won the [[Barry Award (for comedy)|Barry Award]] for this show at the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]], tying with [[Kristen Schaal]].{{cite news |last=Kent |first=Melissa |date=13 April 2008 |title=Top comics grin and share the main prize |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/top-comics-grin-and-share-the-main-prize/2008/04/12/1207856921250.html |newspaper=[[The Age]] |access-date=16 November 2016}} At the Melbourne Comedy Festival 2010 she debuted a new puppet, an elderly woman who is her "Granny". Conti and Granny appeared in episode six of the [[QI (I series)|I series]] of the BBC comedy quiz show ''[[QI]]'' in 2011. On that episode, Conti noted that she inherited the Granny puppet from [[Ken Campbell]] on Campbell's death. In 2012, Conti appeared in ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'' with Granny. She also used a mask on an audience member to persuade him to dance. On the series 8 premiere of ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'', Conti expanded the act to provide voices for two audience members in masks. In March 2013, Conti appeared on ''[[Let's Dance for Comic Relief]]'' with Monk. She danced to "[[I Like to Move It]]" by [[Reel 2 Real]].{{cite news |title=Lets Dance for Comic Relief - Series 5 - Episode 3 |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/tv-programme/e/vhx4w/lets-dance-for-comic-relief--series-5---episode-3 |newspaper=[[Radio Times]] |accessdate=2 March 2013}} In June 2013, Conti appeared on Channel 4's Comedy Gala.{{cite web |url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/channel-4s-comedy-gala/episode-guide/series-6/episode-1 |title=Channel 4's Comedy Gala 2013 |publisher=[[Channel 4]] |accessdate=13 June 2013}} Conti appeared as a guest host on the final episode of the ninth series of the BBC stand-up comedy programme, ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'', performing her act with Monkey and an additional dummy-mask routine. In October 2014, Conti appeared on Channel 4's ''[[The Feeling Nuts Comedy Night]]'' raising awareness of testicular cancer.{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/the-feeling-nuts-comedy-night|title=The Feeling Nuts Comedy Night - All 4|publisher=}} In 2015, Nina appeared on BBC Four's ''Clowning Around'', where she trained to be a giggle doctor and clown, and performed to children in hospitals. In May 2015, Nina appeared on ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown]]'' in Dictionary Corner and used Fabio, the show's regular prop guy, as a dummy. == Radio == Conti's radio work includes ''[[Clare in the Community]]'', ''[[Sneakiepeeks]]'' and guesting on ''[[Parsons and Naylor’s Pull-Out Sections]]''. == Television == Conti's television work began in 2002 with parts in ''[[Black Books]]'' and ''[[Holby City]]''. In 2003 she starred as Mary in a series called ''[[Single (TV series)|Single]]'', then in 2005 voiced characters in another series entitled ''[[Bromwell High]]''. In 2006, 2007 and 2008 she played a part in ''[[Blunder (TV series)|Blunder]]'', ''[[The Golf War]]'' and featured in ''[[Comedy Cuts]]'' respectively. In 2013 Conti, along with her puppet Monk, played a feature role in ''[[Family Tree (TV series)|Family Tree]]'' as Bea Chadwick. ==Filmography== Conti has appeared in a number of diverse forms of media including films, television shows, and shorts, listed below.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0176376/|title=Nina Conti|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! style="width:16em;"| Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1999 | ''The Colour of Funny'' | Sally Bismarck | |- | 2001 | ''Zulu 9'' | Couple - Woman | |- | 2003 | ''Single'' | Mary | TV series |- | 2005 | ''[[Bromwell High]]'' | Latrina | |- | 2006 | ''[[Blunder (TV series)|Blunder]]'' | Various | |- | 2006 | ''[[For Your Consideration (film)|For Your Consideration]]'' | Weather Woman | |- | 2007 | ''The Golf War'' | Susan Oglivy | |- | 2008 | ''[[Comedy Cuts]]'' |Herself | Episode 2.1 |- | 2009 | ''How It's Done'' | Lady of the Book | Short |- on Stage | 2009 | ''Peacock Season'' | Hilly | |- |2011 |''Nina Conti - Talk to the Hand'' |Herself/Writer |live show 2010 |- |2012 |''Nina Conti - A Ventriloquist's Story: Her Master's Voice'' |Herself/Director |documentary |- |2012 |''Make Me Happy: A Monkey’s Search for Happiness '' |Herself/Director |documentary |- | 2013 | ''[[Family Tree (TV series)|Family Tree]]'' | Bea Chadwick and Monk | |- |2014 |''Nina Conti - Dolly Mixtures'' |Herself/Writer |live show 2014 |- | 2014 | ''[[Feeling Nuts Movement|The Feeling Nuts Comedy Night]]'' |Herself | |- |2015 |''Nina Conti Clowning Around'' |Herself/Director |documentary |- |2017-18 |''Nina Conti in Therapy'' |Herself/Co-writer |8 part web series |} ==Characters== ===Monk=== Monk is a cynical monkey who is continually insulting Conti and swearing when he does not have his demands fulfilled. He often deliberately shows irritation towards performing on stage and makes Conti laugh at his words.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2081260/|title=Her Master's Voice|date=6 February 2014|publisher=|via=IMDb}}{{cite news |last=Shoard |first=Catherine |date=15 March 2012 |title=Nina Conti: 'I feel it's not in my film how much I miss Ken' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/mar/15/nina-conti-ventriloquist-ken-campbell |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=16 November 2016}}He now appears in a new cartoon on TV series Pop ===Granny=== Granny is an elderly Scotswoman to whom Conti refers as someone who is a lot like her own grandmother. Granny often chides Conti for the simplest things Conti has done; for instance, when Conti reveals she has two legs, Granny responds by saying "Oh, two legs? You're spoiling me!" Her main act is to telepathically guess numbers or words, which she always guesses correctly. She also talks about her dead husband, Frank. Granny refers to people with words like "dear", "child" or "my daughter". The original prop was donated to [[Vent Haven Museum]] in July 2009, in memory of Ken Campbell, from whom Conti received her, but Conti had a replica made which she continues to use in her acts. ===Face mask=== The face mask, rather than an actual puppet with a personality, is a mask that covers the lower half of an audience participant's face and can be manipulated by a hand-piece held by Conti to make it look like the participant is talking. Conti often uses this to put the participant in awkward and funny situations, such as making them say that they want nothing more than to dance in front of the audience, while their body language suggests the opposite.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I4BB1TZcO_o|title=Nina Conti on Russel Howard's Good News|first=|last=Angela Ritwo|date=2 June 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}} ==Personal life== Conti was in a relationship with the comedian and actor [[Ken Campbell]]; from him she inherited his collection of ventriloquist dummies.{{cite news |last=Johnston |first=Jenny |date=12 July 2012 |title=The ventriloquist who found her voice: Tom Conti's daughter on how her affair with a much older man gave her the confidence to go on stage |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2172824/The-ventriloquist-voice-Tom-Contis-daughter-affair-older-man-gave-confidence-stage.html |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |access-date=16 November 2016}}{{cite news |last=Dessau |first=Bruce |author-link=Bruce Dessau |date=4 May 2013 |title=Nina Conti: The acclaimed ventriloquist on the seductions of acting and throat-singing |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/nina-conti-the-acclaimed-ventriloquist-on-the-seductions-of-acting-and-throat-singing-8599847.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |access-date=16 November 2016}} She was married to Andrew "Stan" Stanley with whom she has had two children.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} On 24 July 2015, Nina received an honorary degree from the University of East Anglia and was made a doctor of letters.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == *{{IMDb name|176376|Nina Conti}} *{{official website|http://www.ninaconti.net}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Conti, Nina}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at King Alfred School, London]] women comedians]] [[Category:Anglo-Scots]] [[Category:Royal Shakespeare Company members]] [[Category:Actresses of Italian descent]] [[Category:20th-century British comedians]] [[Category:21st-century British comedians]]
